title: Limba (1911) Luke
description:
The Limba language, Hulimba, is a Niger-Congo language of Sierra Leone and Guinea. It is not closely related to other languages and appears to form its own branch of the Niger-Congo family, although it was formerly classified as an Atlantic language. Dialects include Tonko, Sela, Kamuke (or Ke), Wara-Wara, Keleng, Biriwa, and Safroko. The eastern variety, spoken primarily in Guinea, is quite distinct. Limba has a system of noun classes, marked by an old, eroded set of prefixes augmented by a newer set of enclitics.

1911 Luke BFBS, London: Translated by Mary L. Clarke and Verna Wesleyan Mission; 1950 John BFBS, London; 1966 New Testament BSS in West Africa Freetown: Translated by Mary L. Clarke, George A. Huff, and others.
